member.name: T:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Controls.WslResizableSidePanelControl
member.summary:
Follow steps 1a or 1b and then 2 to use this custom control in a XAML file.
Step 1a) Using this custom control in a XAML file that exists in the current project. Add this XmlNamespace attribute to the root element of the markup file where it is to be used:
xmlns:MyNamespace="clr-namespace:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Controls"
Step 1b) Using this custom control in a XAML file that exists in a different project. Add this XmlNamespace attribute to the root element of the markup file where it is to be used:
xmlns:MyNamespace="clr-namespace:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Controls;assembly=Keysight.Ccl.Wsl"
You will also need to add a project reference from the project where the XAML file lives to this project and Rebuild to avoid compilation errors:
Right click on the target project in the Solution Explorer and "Add Reference"->"Projects"->[Browse to and select this project]
Step 2) Go ahead and use your control in the XAML file.
<MyNamespace:WslResizableSidePanelControl/>

member.name: T:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.CultureManager
member.summary: CultureManager provides events to notify subscribers when the culture and UI culture of a thread changes. In order to support these notifications, all changes to a thread's culture and UI culture should be done using the CultureManager. Directly setting Thread.CurrentThread.CurrentUICulture will not raise the CultureChanged event and subsequently subscribers like the DynamicResx markup extenion will not get notified when the UI culture changes. CultureManager is a singleton type which can be accessed via the Instance static property.

member.name: P:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.CultureManager.Instance
member.summary: Gets the singleton CultureManager instance.

member.name: P:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.CultureManager.CurrentUICulture
member.summary: Sets the CurrentUICulture on the calling thread and raises the event.

member.name: E:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.CultureManager.CurrentUICultureChanged
member.summary: Raised when the CurrentUICulture property on this type is changed. You must keep a hard reference to the handler to avoid garbage collection and unexpected results. See remarks for more information.
member.remarks: When you subscribe to this event using code, you will need to keep a hard reference to the event handler. You do not need to do this when binding using XAML. This is to prevent garbage collection of the event handler: This event implements the Weak Event pattern, so it does not have a hard reference to this handler.

member.name: P:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.CultureManager.CurrentCulture
member.summary: Sets the CurrentCulture on the calling thread and raises the event.

member.name: E:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.CultureManager.CurrentCultureChanged
member.summary: Raised when the CurrentCulture property on this type is changed. You must keep a hard reference to the handler to avoid garbage collection and unexpected results. See remarks for more information.
member.remarks: When you subscribe to this event using code, you will need to keep a hard reference to the event handler. You do not need to do this when binding using XAML. This is to prevent garbage collection of the event handler: This event implements the Weak Event pattern, so it does not have a hard reference to this handler.

member.summary: Returns the scaling factor that is effectively applied to this window due to the user selecting a custom DPI setting for the Windows OS. member.name: M:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.ScreenManager.UpdateVirtualDesktopRect
member.summary: Queries the system for the available desktop area and working area. The working area is the desktop area minus any docked toolbars, such as the taskbar. The result of this call is that the WslDialog public properties ScreenWorkingArea and DefaultMaxSize, and the GuiUtils.PrimaryMonitorSize property, are updated to match the current reality.

Using a DependencyProperty as the backing store for IsTunnelingEnabled. This enables animation, styling, binding, etc...
Using a DependencyProperty as the backing store for IsBubblingEnabled. This enables animation, styling, binding, etc...

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.HelpManager.HelpLinkProperty
member.summary: The ineritable Attached property that enables any FrameworkElement to look up (bubbling) the visual tree and find a parent Help Link to use as the source of its help

members.member:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Sets bubbling help link. Set it here so that some visual tree child will come up looking for it and use it.
The Help Link object. The Help Link value can be any object. THe default HelpProvider adapter knows how to parse .chm and .pdf formats as well as launch arbitrary OS file extensions. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

summary.para: Manages platform differences by applying OS-specific XAML resources.
If the manager detects a certain Microfosoft Windows version it will automaticaly apply any Xaml that you have specified in an OS specific skin
See the ExperimentalFeaturesSample sample app for an example of how to use the Platform manager

member.name: M:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.PlatformManager.ClearPlatformResources

member.name: T:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategoryPermutations
member.summary: The various supported relationships that skins can have with categories

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategoryPermutations.None
member.summary: Represents no relationship between this skin and this category

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategoryPermutations.OneOfN
member.summary: Declares that the skin only gets one choice of a dependent skin of a mutually exclusive group but it has to have at least one at all times

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategoryPermutations.ZeroOrOne
member.summary: Declares that the skin can optionally have none or at most one of the dependent skin type

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategoryPermutations.ZeroOrOneOfN
member.summary: Declares that the skin can optionally have none or if not it must have one choice of a dependent skin of a mutually exclusive group

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategoryPermutations.Any
member.summary: Represents a unique relationship where any permutation is valid

member.name: T:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories
member.summary: The various supported skins categories that give semantics to skin instances

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories.None
member.summary: Represents the absence of any kind of category. It usually means no formal category was ever registered/configured for this skin. Highly unusual.

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories.Supported
member.summary: Opposite of the UnSupported category. Very generic category meaning TLO supports it. Could be custom, vanilla, fragement, full, color, font, touch etc. Doesn't care this just means is it releasable and will be supported by TLO

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories.Unsupported
member.summary: Oppostive of the Supported category. Very generic category meaning TLO doesn't support it. Could be custom, vanilla, fragement, full, color, font, touch etc. Doesn't care this just means it is unreleasable and will be not supported by TLO

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories.Foundational
member.summary: Opposite of the Fragment category. A skin of this type is meant to be the foundation for a certain look. It simply means a main skin that should provide the core of the look and provide most of the control templates. It can either be a MS provided one, a 3rd party or our own. It is typically a custom skin that we provide but does not have to be. The MS sytem skin is a good example of a foundational skin that is not necessarily customized by us.

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories.Fragment
member.summary: Opposite of the Foundational category. A skin of this type is meant to simply be a xaml adder. Provides additional xaml to augment or override some aspects of the currently defined visual tree

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories.System
member.summary: Opposite of the Custom category. A skin of this type is meant to be totally compatible with the default vanilla MS look and behavior. In fact they are supposed to either pass through the MS templates, copy them verbatim and only make VERY minor mods

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories.Custom
member.summary: Opposite of the System category. A skin that has significant custom styling and templating. Don't infer much else other than it is a TLO created item

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories.Color
member.summary: A skin that has provides color values for all the color brushes found in the base Color Skin fragment

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories.CustomChrome
member.summary: A skin that has significant custom styling and templating in the chrome area (border, titlebar, etc.) area

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories.Test
member.summary: A skin that is meant for internal test purposes only

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories.Sample
member.summary: A skin that is meant for external sample purposes only

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories.UserSelectable
member.summary: Opposite of the Hidden cateogry. A skin of this type is meant for an end user to discover and apply it

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories.Hidden
member.summary: Opposite of the UserSelectable cateogry. A skin of this type is not meant to be applied or discovered given a certain context. If it is to be applied it is not to be the result of a user selection.

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories.Any
member.summary: Represents a unique relationship where any category is valid

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories.Active
member.summary: Opposite of the Inactive category. Represents a skin that is currently merged into the app wide resource dictionary

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCategories.Inactive
member.summary: Opposite of the Active category. Represents a skin that is not currently merged into the app wide resource dictionary

member.name: T:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMergeOrder
member.summary: The merge order that skins can declare with each other as part of their relationships

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMergeOrder.Denied
member.summary: Represents no merge order relationship meaning it won't be merged at all. NOTE: This relationship does not actually result in a merge

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMergeOrder.Descendent
member.summary: This group of skins will be merged first (before the next group)

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMergeOrder.Child
member.summary: This group of skins will be merged second (after the previous and just before the depender)

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMergeOrder.Me
member.summary: This category represents the skin itself

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMergeOrder.Parent
member.summary: This group of skins will be merged first (after the depender and before the next group)

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMergeOrder.Ancestor
member.summary: This group of skins will be merged second (after the previous and before the next group)

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMergeOrder.Any
member.summary: Represents no particular order. This is a unique relationship that causes any merge order relationship to be valid. NOTE: This relationship does not actually result in a merge

member.name: T:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMergeStatus
member.summary: The merge status as a result of an attempted application of a skin

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMergeStatus.Success
member.summary: The merge was successfull. The skin was applied.

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMergeStatus.Fail
member.summary: Opposite of the success relationship. The skin was not applied

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMergeStatus.Denied
member.summary: The relationship and or context was such that this skin was denied from being merged or applied. The skin was not applied

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMergeStatus.Canceled
member.summary: A registered handler of the merge event cancelled the merge process. They had better know what they are doing. The skin was not applied

member.name: T:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCompatibility
member.summary: The various compatibility relationships that skins can have with each other

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCompatibility.Incompatible
member.summary: The skins are so incompatible that the depender denies the merging of the dependee. If they were allowed to co-exist the system would crash or other really bad things would happen

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCompatibility.NotRecommended
member.summary: The skins are incompatible but not to the point of denying a merge at the skin merge level. Things may look bad but not worth failing the merge

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCompatibility.Ambivalent
member.summary: These two skins weren't made for each other or weren't made to compliment each other. The merge is allowed to happen but the overall visual appearance will not be enhanced.

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCompatibility.Me
member.summary: A special category identify the middle ground and/or the skin itself

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCompatibility.Optional
member.summary: Declares a complimentary skin that is neither required nor turned on by default. They can come and go. They enhance the visual design. Ambient skin fragments and color scheme skin fragments are usually marked as optional.

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCompatibility.Recommended
member.summary: Similar to the required relationship. The relationship begins as a requirement but can be removed and similar to the optional relationship it will live and look good without it. Skin fragments that really do improve the look of a foundational skin are usually marked as recommended. The system will allow an unregistration of this relationship.

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCompatibility.Required
member.summary: The relationship is required. The depender cannot live without this relationship. If the dependent skin is not present the system will crash or the look and feel will be severely impaired. The system does not allow a removal of this relationship. Not even with a call to UnregisterSkinRelationship. Once setup it will live forever. The skin creator will need to change the skin definition/configuration if users/partners don't like/want this relationship

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinCompatibility.Any
member.summary: Declares a unique relationsihp where any compatibility level is valid. Usually used in the matching/querying API's. NOTE: Does not result in a merge.

member.name: T:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMiscRelationships
member.summary: The various miscelleneous relationships that skins can have with each other that are not required, are ambient, and is used to eventually declare an extensibility point in the API.

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMiscRelationships.None
member.summary: Represents a unique relationship where none of the possible relationships are active. Highly unusual but may be meaningful given certain circumstances.

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMiscRelationships.Color
member.summary: Represents a special relationship between skins that indicates the callee provides color/coloring to the caller. A nice way to recognize a relationship that consists of a color scheme rather than querying each and every skin in a dependency tree to "guess" at which one might be the active color scheme for that skin

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMiscRelationships.Ambient
member.summary: Represents a special relationship between skins that indicates the callee provides xaml look for all existing foundational skins that don't have an incompatible relationship. It an environmental/ambient skin fragment meant to enhance the look for all skins

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMiscRelationships.Any
member.summary: Represents a unique relationship where all possible relationships are active. Highly unusual but may be meaningful given certain circumstances

member.name: T:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMatchingModes
member.summary: The rules to use when finding skins based on their relationship to each other

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMatchingModes.None
member.summary: Represents the absence of any kind of matching mode

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMatchingModes.Exclusive
member.summary: The relationship with the dependent skins must exactly match the desired realtionship to the exclusion of all other relationships. Meaning it won't be a match if it include more or less than the desired relationship

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMatchingModes.Inclusive
member.summary: The relationship with the dependent skins must at least include all the desired realtionship but can include additional relationships as well. Meaning it won't be a match if it includes less than the desired relationship

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMatchingModes.Not
member.summary: The relationship with the dependent skin should not include any of the categories

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMatchingModes.TraverseRelationships
member.summary: The algorithm should traverse all relationships of the target skin to all leaf nodes in the relationship hierarchy looking for matches.

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMatchingModes.TraverseMergeRelationships
member.summary: The algorithm should traverse all merge relationships of the target skin to all leaf nodes in the relationship hierarchy looking for matches.

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMatchingModes.TwoWay
member.summary: The algorithm should check for a matching relationship between both the caller and callee and also the callee and the caller. Both directions.

member.name: F:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Managers.SkinMatchingModes.Any
member.summary: As long as the relationship doesn't match the "None" relationship it will return true For comparison purposes it acts like the "Inclusive" mode but it can be used as a "special" flag to query and return skins that have *ANY* kind of relationship Essentially represents that any mode is valid

member.name: M:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.MarkupExtensions.UpdateableMarkupExtensionManager.RemoveAllInactiveExtensions
member.summary: Removes all the markup extensions that are inactive i.e. whose target is no longer considered alive. This removes a strong reference to the markup extension so that it can be garbage collected.
member.remarks: This method is called periodically as new objects are registered to remove objects which no longer need to be updated because their target is no longer alive.

member.summary: The Resource key to retrieve

member.name: P:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.MarkupExtensions.StaticResxExtension.Static
member.summary:
A static value expression like props:Resources.HelloWorld in the same format as used in the x:Static extension. This uses the strongly typed resources but avoids any of the lookups to find the resource manager.
When using this syntax to point at strongly typed resources you don't need to specify a ResourceSet or Assembly because it these are explicitly tied to the strongly typed resource.

member.name: P:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.MarkupExtensions.StaticResxExtension.ResourceSet

member.summary: A default value that is returned when the the resource cannot be resolved. Also returned in the designer if there are no resources available.

member.name: P:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.MarkupExtensions.StaticResxExtension.Format
member.summary: A string.Format format string that is applied. Note when provided the result value is always converted into a string.

member.summary: Allows to specify a custom Value Converter using standard WPF syntax.

member.summary: The default value to use if the resource can't be found.
member.remarks: This particularly useful for properties which require non-null values because it allows the page to be displayed even if the resource can't be loaded.

member.name: P:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.MarkupExtensions.DynamicResxExtension.ResxName
member.summary: The fully qualified name of the embedded resx (without .resources) to get the resource from.
member.remarks: If not specified, the attached property DefaultResxName is inspected to provide the ResxName. If that is not specified, then the ultimate fallback is the namespace of the associated XAML's root object. This supports the scenario where a .resx file is sitting behind the associated .xaml file (by hand editing the .csproj file and setting the DependentUpon element of the resx file to refer to the XAML file.

member.name: M:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Resources.Skins.Skin.OnMerging(System.ComponentModel.CancelEventArgs)
member.summary: Raises the MergingEvent event.
member.param: A CancelEventArgs that contains the event data.

remarks.para: Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see Raising an Event.
The OnMerging method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
Notes to Inheritors
When overriding OnMerging in a derived class, be sure to call the base class's OnMerging method so that registered delegates receive the event.

remarks.para: Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see Raising an Event.
The OnUnmerged method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
Notes to Inheritors
When overriding OnUnmerged in a derived class, be sure to call the base class's OnUnmerged method so that registered delegates receive the event.

member.name: M:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.Dialogs.AboutBox.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Uri)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The name of the application. It should be in the form of "{product_name}".

The detailed version number of the application. This is typically in the form "Version: {major}.{minor}.{build}.{revision}". You may append additional information about the product's version status such as "Alpha", "Beta" or "Preview".

The copyright dates for the product. All Keysight products should display copyright information. This dates should specify dates of the product's release and can vary in form from "2010" to "2002-2010" to "1998, 2000, 2003-2010". See the corporate branding site for more info on displaying copyright dates: http://marketing.keysight.com/brand/copyright_format.shtml.
The Uri to the application's icon. This should be a 64x64 pixel image that supports transparency if the icon is non-rectangular.

member.name: E:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.DelegateCommand`1.CanExecuteChanged
member.summary: Occurs when changes occur that affect whether or not the command should execute. You must keep a hard reference to the handler to avoid garbage collection and unexpected results. See remarks for more information.
member.remarks: When you subscribe to the event using code, you will need to keep a hard reference to the event handler. (You do not need to do this when binding using XAML.) This is to prevent garbage collection of the event handler: The command implements the Weak Event pattern, so it does not have a hard reference to this handler. In most scenarios, there is no reason to sign up for the CanExecuteChanged event directly, but if you do, you are responsible for maintaining the reference.

member.name: M:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.WslDialog.WslDialog_Closed(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Closing event handler. Special code added here to work-around a bug in the WPF windows management. The defect occurs when "owner-nested" dialog are opened and then closed in reverse order. When the last child dialog is closed, the main application window would fall back in the z-order relative to other active applications. The work-around is to call Activate() on the Owner window of the dialog being closed.

member.name: M:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.WslMainWindow.WindowStateChanged(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: StateChanged event handler. Look for window state changes. All other maximize requests from Windows (right-click on taskbar, etc) are caught and "swallowed" by the custom WndProc() message hook. Unfortunately, when a window is maximized by way of the Windows 7 Snap feature (drag window to top of screen), it does not send the WM_SYSCOMMAND/SC_MAXIMIZE message and somehow directly maximizes the window. We therefore have to manage this by catching the WindowState changed event and updating any visuals (like the max/restore button) Since we have to do this for the Windows "Snap" feature we funnel any WindowState changes through here

member.name: M:Keysight.Ccl.Wsl.UI.WslMainWindow.SavePreMaximizedState
member.summary: Saves the visual state before the MainWindow is maximized so that it can be restored. Very important if the SizeToContent property is set to "HeightAndWidth". This state needs to be saved and restored since it will be overriden to properly support maximizing the mainwindow Also sets some important properties (which are later restored) to allow animations to work.

member.summary: Restores the visual state to undo minimized.
